results.notes:
This colorful growth was in a sap flow from sapsucker wells on a mature paper birch.
It did not return the following spring and I didn’t keep track of it through the 2019 season.
The color suggests a yeast maybe related to Cystofilobasidium macerans or Fuscicola merismoides, but this was thin and not gelatinous like those and redder. It was dry when photographed and I did not detect any distinct odor.

results.notes:
Ecology – gregarious-cespitose, fruiting beneath/lifting up bare gravelly soil layer; under Arctostaphylos sp./Ceanothus sp./(possible Pinus sabiniana within 50 m); inland transverse range habitat, north facing chaparral slope at 1030 m
Pileus – convex to broadly umbonate then flat with upturned margin; dry, glabrous to silky; cream white when young, darkening to yellow-brown where handled, mature specimens yellow-brown with cream colored fibrils which rub off
Veil – fine cortina-like veil, disappearing
Lamellae – white to cream when young, darkening somewhat in age or not at all
Stipe – equal with rimmed basal bulb; dry, longitudinally striate, finely pruinose throughout; creamy buff to carnate, darkening in age
Odor – slight bitter or indistinct
Context – white with slight flesh tones

results.notes: Fruiting in a newly developed neighborhood/construction site. Construction began here Summer 2022. Recorded the location and returned again today(4/17/23). Abundant fruiting surrounding a newly installed lamppost/street lamp(installed during construction Summer 2022.  Microclimate created by heat/vibration from lamps overnight. All fruiting bodies within 3 ft. of lamp post bases. We have noted this occurrence under lampposts with M. importuna for over 10yrs in new developments(most abundant flushes always beneath lampposts). Note the ladder like/vertically arranged pits. Harvested numerous mature specimens for culinary use(left multiple young fruits to mature over remainder of Spring season here). Dehydrating a single specimen for herbarium collection/genetic record with this observation.
results.location_name: Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
On a hardwood log, probable ash.
Spores smooth, ellipsoid to slightly bean-shaped; 7-8(9) x 4-5, with 1-3 guttules or indistinct contents. Not reactive in Melzer’s.
Smash mount of gill material did not reveal any structures that are obviously cystidia. Possibly a few are cystidia, but if so then I did not recognize as different from the basidia.
When I found these I thought they were Galerina marginata. But, the spore print is yellow and the spores are much different than those of G. marginata. These spores are smooth and none show a subapical depression (plage).

results.notes:
On the cut end of a large log. This area features lots of piled logs, the result of tree being downed during a wind storm ~4 years ago. The logs are mostly hemlock and oak; difficult to tell which is which. What remained of the bark on this log looked more like oak than hemlock. But, the stubs form old limbs appeared to be oriented perpendicular to the log/trunk.
These likely began fruiting during 2022.
Surprisingly, this dropped a substantial spore print; white.
Spores 11-14(15) x 4-5(5.5); non reactive in Melzer’s; arched near the apiculus (seen when favorably profiled). Viewed through my better scope at 400x (no photo available) the spores appeared to be finely punctate. Not sure about this.

results.notes:
Fruiting beneath Douglas fir with most fruits attached to buried wood-chips.
Odor: slightly spermatic.
Harvested 3 specimens.
Spore Print: pale brown/faint.
Mounted slide with 2 individual gill slices in KOH.
Microscopy: images of work included.
Cheilocystidia: Thick walled Metuloid, encrusted tips. Yellow in KOH.
Pleurocystidia: balloon shaped, turbinate, large, rather abundant.
Lamellar trama/hyphae: clamp connections abundant.
Basidia: 4 sterigmate.
Spores: mostly amygdaliform(almond shaped), some inequilateral/curved crescent. Largest spores viewed are longer and nearly torpedo shaped. Approximately 10um x 5um.
Dehydrated all 3 specimens and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes:
Abundant fruiting on a Douglas fir cone.
Counted 19 specimens on this single host cone.
Harvested cone and all attached fruiting bodies.
Removed a single specimen and performed a crush mount on glass slide with cap tissue. Mounted in KOH.
Microscopy Notes: images of work included-
Spores: oval shaped, very small, slightly yellow in KOH.
Asci: 8 spored. Blue in KOH. Amyloid.
Paraphyses: clear, lacking septa, filiform(very long/slender).
Cap tissue/pileipellis: cellular, hymeniform, angular cells.
Dehydrated entire Doug fir cone with specimens attached and then removed each fully dehydrated specimen afterward. Bagged all 19 dehydrated specimens for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes:
Fruiting in a newly developed neighborhood/construction site. Construction began at this location during Summer 2022. Recorded the location and returned again today(4/22/23). Abundant fruiting in grass surrounding a newly installed lamppost/street lamp(installed during construction Summer 2022).  Microclimate created by heat/vibration from lamps overnight. All fruiting bodies within 3 ft. of lamp post bases. We have noted this occurrence under lampposts with M. importuna for over 10yrs in new developments(most abundant flushes always beneath lampposts). Note the ladder like/vertically arranged pits. Harvested 11 specimens for culinary use(left multiple young fruits to mature over remainder of Spring season here).
This is the 2nd new development site on my 2023 list that has begun producing fruiting bodies so far this Spring.
Dehydrating all specimens for future use and bagging a single specimen for herbarium collection/genetic record with this observation.
results.location_name: Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
I’m not sure of the type of wood. The large downed tree trunk lacked both branch stubs and bark.
These fruit bodies were immature at the time of this observation. No spores dropped and material smash-mounted showed what appear to be small underdeveloped asci. I left a few in-situ and will return next week to hopefully get some mature material.
I think the likely ID for this is G. ancilis. However, other material collected at this site has been sequenced and matched with G. warnei obs 452101 (in addition to G. ancilis and G. perlata, names which may represent the same taxon).

Mycoquebec gives spore dimensions for M. alcalina as having smaller widths than what I observed in all three of the 4/22/2023 Moon Lake collections seen here on MO. Also, Mycoquebec reports cheilocystidia that are narrower and without a projection. Cheilocystidia seen via the following link look much the same as I found on my Moon Lake collections http://website.nbm-mnb.ca/... . results.notes: The specimen was found in very wet conditions on a rainy day in a deciduous forest. The fungi were growing likely saprotrophically on a decomposing log in sporadic fan-shaped clusters. The entire basidiocarp was very rubbery and flexible. The hymenium was exposed and featured split gills that were gray to brown in color. The upper surface was gray to white with light pink bands and the edge was noticeably split and wavy. A small stipe was observed but the overall appearance was that of a shelf fungi. When the collected specimen dried, the upper surface was also noticeably hairy and much lighter in color.

results.notes: Toothed hymenium. Found growing on a standing dead tree.

results.notes: The specimen was found in very wet conditions on a rainy day in a deciduous forest. The fungi seemed to be growing saprotrophically on a decomposing log in fan-shaped clusters that were often curled and wavy. The upper surface features bands of reddish-brown to orange with a light-colored edge. The upper surface was also notably hairy and soft and had algae growing near the base. The hymenium was majority smooth and brownish-orange to cream-colored at the edge. No clear stipe was observed. The specimen collected dried to be whitish/gray in color.
results.location_name: Eagle Heights Woods, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes:
Accidentally Cultivated this in a sealed plastic tote full of sawdust + Rice Flour + Gypsum powder which was soaked in boiling water and forgotten about for maybe 3 weeks.
Opened the tote up about a week ago just to hose it down with H2O2 and kill off all the Trich on the surface so I could dump it without breathing in too much, and then left it until now.

So whatever this milky yellow slime mold is, it’s thriving in low O2, very high moisture, on trich-contaminated pasteurized sawdust which has had it’s air-exposed surfaces soaked with H2O2.

results.notes:
Growing scattered on bits of woody debris, sticks and logs washed up among herbarceous plants in a hardwood floodplain forest composed almost entirely of Acer negundo with scattered Arundinaria gigantea. Basidiocarps single or caespitose. Caps hygrophanous; slightly sticky when fresh; smooth; 7.0 to 40.8 mm wide and 4.2 to 12.0 mm tall at maturity; occasionally papillate. Gills adnexed. Veil present in primordia and forming a thin annulus on mature stems. Stems 30.5 to 58.9 mm long and 1.2 to 8.3 mm wide at maturity; normally even but occasionally widening toward either the base or the apex; fibrous; attached to copious white rhizomorphs. All surfaces bluing strongly. Strong “Psilocybe” odor.

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 173804675 on July 19, 2023.

results.notes:
On the ground in area with apple trees and various hardwoods.
Spores with a knob/flap at each pole, 27-35 × 11-14 (including “knobs”). Many with one large central guttule and two smaller ones.
I’ve been calling these “korfii” for years. But, I wonder if at least some of my collections have been G. americanigigas. According to Mycoquebec, the spores representing this collection have dimensions more in line with americanigigas. in particular, the Q expectation for korfii appears to favor values near or exceeding 3.0 (including the polar knobs). The Q values for the spores seen in this observation are mainly 2.4<Q<2.8 with none found at or exceeding 3.0.

results.notes:
This mushroom seemed to be dried out by the sun and was very hard (almost as hard as a rock).

It was growing by a small coniferous tree on the Canadian Shield with very minimal shade from the sun.

It is unlike any mushroom I’ve seen.
It has a very short stem, undulate margin and the teeth are coming out the top of the cap, growing vertically upwards rather than underneath. I’ve never seen or heard of a mushroom with teeth on the cap.

results.notes:
Same fruiting as obs 518558, one week later.
On rotting log, probably hemlock.
No spore drop after >24 hours.
Spores seen via smash mount, some clearly immature but mature ones with 1-2 large guttules and 1-2 smaller ones. Poles with blunt, rounded, or acute flaps/knobs that darken in Congo red. Discounting the polar flaps, 25-33 × 11-13 (up to 37 microns long when the flaps are included).
These were first seen on 2/21. I lefts several in situ to mature. No spore drop obtained, but perhaps the spores are expelled in large groups when a fruit body is first disturbed and then none are released for an extended period. I left two of these in situ to (perhaps) further mature.
results.location_name: Ricketts Glen State Park, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
On a rotting log, probably hemlock.
First observed on 4/21, left in situ to mature.
No spore drop. Spores seen via smash mount. Some with rounder or subtriangular/tapered polar flaps/knobs. 20-27 × 10-13 discounting the knobs. It appeared that some of the knobs (ornamentation) had dissolved in the Congo red. See second photo of spores where darkened residue is seen near the poles.
results.location_name: Ricketts Glen State Park, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Solitary fruit body on a large mossy hemlock log.
No spore drop. Most spores seen via smash mount appeared to be immature. Some (mature?) spores with a knob on one r both poles. Only one spore measured, 21 × 10. A few spores with pointed polar flaps.
results.location_name: Ricketts Glen State Park, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Fruiting in grass a few feet from a lamppost in a newly developed neighborhood zone. Construction here began during summer of 2022. We returned today to check suitable habitat for Morchella importuna.
All specimens encountered at this location today are stunted/dried out from drastic heat spike in the last week. Temps jumped from low 50’s for a daily high to low 80’s essentially overnight and hovered there for entire week.
Note vertically arranged/ladder like pits.
Harvested 2 specimens and dehydrated for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes:

NO VEIL.

Taste: bitter.

Mounted gill tissue in KOH on a separate slide for analysis.

Spores: elliptical/oval shaped, verrucose/warted, rather small. Ferruginous(reddish brown) in KOH.
Slightly curved in side laying spores.
Cheilocystidia: ventricose/capitate.
Dehydrated all specimens and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes:
This fruiting body was found growing on the side of a fallen tree. It is tough and has a bracket-form and concentric circles of growth are seen on the top. The upper surface is mostly white and grey with some brown and green near the base (where it connects to the tree). There is no stalk present. The underside is characterized by white/cream/brown color and circular pores which contain hymenia holding basidiospores.

The book “Mushrooms of Northeast North America” by George Barron was used to help identify this specimen.

results.notes:
This fungus has a black fruiting body (also called a stroma) that was formed on the branch of a young tree. The surface of the stroma is hard and bumpy and covered with papillae. The papillae are young psuedothecia and will eventually contain the asci and ascospores. These structures are more easily seen under the dissecting microscope in the third and fourth images.

The book “Ascomycete Fungi of North America” by Michael W. Beug, Alan E. Bessette, and Arleen R. Bessette was used to help identify this specimen.

results.notes:
Growing on the leaves of a fallen Quercus nigra twig partially covered by a Pinus taeda log. Caps appearing powdery, white when fresh and remaining white dried. Stems spiny with small basal discs. Pileipellis elements rounded, thick walled and with short spines. Cherocytes present on the pileipellis, with occasional spines bearing spinulae. Lactifers present in the stipe trama. Caulocystidia densely spinose. Lamellar trama dextrinoid. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia hyaline with short spines. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores weakly amyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (6) 6.4 – 8 (9) × (3.3) 3.9 – 4.6 (4.9) µm; Q = (1.4); 1.6 – 1.9 (2.1); N = 30; Me = 7.2 × 4.2 µm; Qe = 1.7

results.notes: The specimen was found on a downed log in a mesic deciduous forest. At the time of collection, the specimen also seemed to be quite old and dried. On the wood, the fungus was reddish brown and exhibited a distinct honeycomb pattern that was likely remnants of tightly clustered structures housing sporangia. Threadlike masses were also seen draped from the honeycomb structures. A sample was taken for further microscopic analysis. At 400x magnification, capillitia and spores were clearly discernable. The spores were smooth with little ornamentation and the capillitia were spiraled and spiny.

results.notes: The specimen was found growing on a broken tree branch that had fallen on the ground in a deciduous forest. The lichen was notably foliose with a yellow upper cortex. The lobes were overlapping and pycnidia were observed under a dissecting microscope. The lower cortex was much paler in color and the entire thallus was growing alongside and on top of a second lichen. A K+ test was also performed and the upper cortex responded by turning dark reddish purple– a strong indicator for Xanthoria.

results.notes:
Yellow sporangia with a slender stalk with a funnel-shaped, shallow calyculus. Found on the underside of rotten wood by Picnic Point.
The slime is yellow in color, including the apothecia, thread, and spores. The capillitial threads are 5-7 micro meters in diameter, with even, smooth, spiral bands. They are branched and webbed. The colony was around 3.5mm in length, and the opened apothecia approximately 0.5-1cm in diameter.
A slide with threads and water was prepared, and it was investigated at 400x with a compound microscope. There was no evidence of tapering ends. There were branched, evenly-spiraled bands. The spores were dull-yellow and round in shape.
results.location_name: Picnic Point, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes:
The thallus is blue-gray, wrinkled and folded, with many small lobules on the thallus. The lower surface is pale, and it has pale rhizines. The apothecia is usually abundant (although this one did not have any). This was found on a fallen branch near a trail, and it is typically found on the bark of decaying trees in open woodlands or roadsides, and it is found in Wisconsin. This fungi was approximately 6cm in diameter, with apothecia typically 3-15mm in diameter, and lobes 2-6mm wide.
This one specifically seems to have an algal growth.
In addition, chemical tests were preformed to confirm the identity:
- cortex: K+ yellow
- medulla: K-, C-, KC-, UV-
Reference:
Brodo, I. M., Duran Sharnoff, S., & Sharnoff, S. (2001). Lichens of north America. Yale University Press.
results.location_name: Picnic Point, UW-Madison Lakeshore Nature Preserve, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

results.notes:
Habitat:
• inside and outside forests, commonly in light, sunny, dry places
• Dead or called wood
• Present throughout the year

Distinguishing characteristics:
• white to gray caps
• Dry
• Fan to shell shaped
• White spore print
• No veil
• Absent or narrow extension of the cap stipe
• Lamellae is pink flesh-colored, fanning out
• The edges are split and turned up when dry and closed when moist
• When moist—elastic and tough
• When dry— shriveled and hard
• Spores are cyclindric
• Basidia have 4 sterigmata and basal clamp

• upper surface: densely covered with tiny hairs, dry surface, white to grayish white
• Margin incurved to inrolled when young, often becoming wavy and torn with age
• Gills: white to pinkish-gray, split lengthwise along the free edge, usually serrated or torn
• Stalk: absent or rudimentary
• Flesh: thin, flexible
• Spores: 5-7.5 × 2-3 micro meters, cyclindic and smooth
• Occur: solitary, scattered, or overlapping clusters
• Decaying wood often in NE, N central and South regions year round
• Found on all continents except Antarctica
Measurements: the caps are around 1-4.5 coming wide
References:
https://www.messiah.edu/...
Polypores and similar fungi citation:
“Bessette, A. E., Smith, D., & Bessette, A. R. (2021). Polypores and similar fungi of eastern and central north America. University of Texas Press.”

Mushrooms of the Midwest:
“ Kuo, M., & Methven, A. S. (2014). Mushrooms of the Midwest. University of Illinois Press.”

results.notes:
This was found on a fallen tree branch, and Physcia is usually found on decaying vegetation. The lobes are under 3mm in diameter. The apothecia is 1.5mm at the largest. The thallus is gray in color, and the lower surface is pale in color. The apothecia is present, and the disks are typically dark brown/black in color. The lichen is growing directly on the bark. In this specific example, there are yellow/orange lobes, which were K+ red. It is possible that it is Xanthoria.
Reference:
Brodo, I. M., Duran Sharnoff, S., & Sharnoff, S. (2001). Lichens of north America. Yale University Press.

results.notes: I found the slime mold on a rotting stump in Muir woods. The fruiting body was orange and dusty, clearly it was sporulating. Once I brought it back to the lab, i was able to identify it as a Trichiales. Using my dissecting scope I was able to see that the sporangia was sessile, crowded, somewhat flattened, and red-brown. I was between Perichaena depressa and Prototrichia metallica but I was able to differentiate the two with its capillitia. I separated a small amount of capillitia from the fruiting body and made a slide. The capillitia was clearly belonging to Perichaena depressa, it was slender and a bit spiny.

results.notes:
Very large/mature fruiting in a newly developed neighborhood/construction site. Construction began at this location Summer 2022. Recorded the location and returned today(5/5/23). Abundant fruiting surrounding a newly installed lamppost/street lamp(installed during construction Summer 2022).  Microclimate created by heat/vibration from lamps overnight. All fruiting bodies within 3 ft. of lamp post bases. We have noted this occurrence under lampposts with M. importuna for over 10yrs in new developments(most abundant flushes always beneath lampposts).  Note the ladder like/vertically arranged pits. 
Harvested all 8 specimens.

Largest fruiting body in this collection weighed in at 3.621oz.
Bisecting and dehydrating all fruits for later culinary use.
Bagging a single dehydrated specimen for herbarium collection/genetic record with this observation.
